section.title: GDI Interface
section.para: This is an module-based interface to the Windows GDI32.dll, to allow writing native Windows GUI's.

The package GDI is case-sensitive, e.g., you would need to use the command-line option &opt-modern; or be in &cs-clu; package, and write (GDI::CreateFontA ...) when you need to call the &c-lang; function CreateFontA. See
section.simpara: When this module is present, &features-my; contains the symbol :GDI.
section.para: See modules/gdi/p1.lisp or modules/gdi/p2.lisp for sample usage.

section.title: Structs
section.para: All data is kept on the &c-lang; side as much as possible, there are no &clos; counterparts. Structs not listed are treated as opaque &foreign-pointer;.
Struct names are uppercase matching the Windows struct name, the constructor is lowercase with the make- prefix.

listitem.simpara: Constructor (make-rgb r g b), predefined instances are *black* and *white*.
Constructor (make-point &optional-amp; x y), x and y are of type integer.
Constructor (make-point-float &optional-amp; x y), x and y are of type short-float.

section.section:
GDI Functions Argument types: int DWORD WORD LONG UINT LPARAM arguments are mapped to direct &integer-t; types. All strings are converted automativally from and to (LPCSTR, LPCWSTR, ...), just some output args are kept as &foreign-pointer;. All handles (ATOM, H*) which are no explicitly handled structs from above must be &foreign-pointer; types. See the process* functions in local.c
Return values: Generally, on failure &nil; as first value and GetLastError (&integer-t;) as second value is returned. BOOL GDI functions return on success just &t;. integer GDI functions return the returned integer. The other functions returning a struct may return them as &foreign-pointer; or if listed above as struct. Some functions which in c would return a struct return multiple values if it was more convenient to do so. For example GetTextExtentPoint32A would return a SIZE as &foreign-pointer;, but most of the time, the size will be used directly. If this proves not to be the case, change it.
(AddFontResourceA LPCSTR)
See MSDN
Returns a &integer-t;. On failure &nil; and as second value the error code as &integer-t; is returned. (AddFontResourceW LPCWSTR)
See MSDN

See MSDN
Draws the specified HCURSOR. Returns the handle of the previously displayed cursor. Note that the cursor will change back to the default one as soon as the mouse moves or a system command is performed. To change the cursor persistantly, use ChangeCursor.
Returns a foreign pointer to the HCURSOR structure. (GetCursor)
See MSDN
Returns the handle of the current cursor. Returns a foreign pointer to the HCURSOR structure. (ChangeCursor HWND HCURSOR)
See MSDN
Changes the default cursor for a window to CURSOR. Returns a foreign pointer to the previous HCURSOR (GetCursorPos LPPOINT)
See MSDN
Gets the absolute mouse cursor position. Returns the x and y coordinate of the mouse. Or &nil; (SetCursorPos int int)
See MSDN
Moves the mouse cursor to the specified screen coordinates. Accepts x und y integers. Returns &t; or &nil; (GetCursorInfo PCURSORINFO)
See MSDN
Sets the slots in the record PCURSORINFO. Returns &t; or &nil;
(SetDCPenColor HDC COLORREF)

varlistentry.para: Prepare collecting all OnCreate callbacks. The results is on startup stored in *hinstance*.
Return the tmascent slot of the hfont.
Return the tmdescent slot of the hfont.
This function is similar to the clx function draw-arc. To avoid using optional arguments, args are passed in as POINTs.
